title: what frankie dettori told meghan markle royal ascot 2018
story: Prince Harry wagged his finger at the diminutive Italian as the athlete joked his kids would be more excited about his meeting Meghan Markle than him winning the race.The 47-year-old had just won the St Jamess Palace Stakes on horse Without Parole on Tuesday, putting the 33-year-old royal on his guard when he pecked Meghan on the hand.The 5ft 4in sportsman today revealed what sparked Prince Harrys sudden reaction, telling Ladbrokes: I told her my kids will be more excited about me meeting you than me winning the race, but then Harry started wagging his finger!Despite Frankies nonchalance, he actually didnt break protocol.According to royal.uk there are no obligatory codes of behaviour when meeting The Queen or a member of the Royal Family.But there was a sting for the jockey, who was suspended and fined £4,300 for using his whip above the permitted level from approaching two furlongs out during his winning race.The Duke and Duchess had caused a sensation when they arrived at the event earlier this week.The newlyweds arrived in a horse-drawn carriage alongside the Count and Countess of Wessex.They were followed swiftly by the Queen, wearing a bright yellow jacket and matching hat, who was accompanied by her daughter, Princess Anne.Meghan, wearing a elegant white dress and Harry in top and tails, waved to excited crowds who had packed out the race course in Berkshire.Their appearance at the eagerly anticipated race event came hours after Kensington Palace announced that their first official foreign trip as a couple would be to Dublin, in July. Prince Charles and the Duchess of Cornwall were also spotted arriving at Royal Ascot with Princesses Eugenie and Beatrice travelling in another carriage, after.Missing from the royal party was Zara Phillips and Mike Tindall, who announced the birth of their second child earlier that day.Armed cops had been seen patrolling the race tracks bars and enclosures.Recent race days have been marred by unsavoury booze-fuelled antics, with video footage emerging of a mass brawl between men at Ascot in May.The incident took place a week after another man was filmed being kicked in the head during a fight at Goodwood races in Sussex.Goodwood chiefs are so sick of the bad behaviour that they have limited punters to buying fours drinks one time.However, it is not thought that Ascot has taken similar measures. Meghan has appeared comfortable in filling her new role as a royal, having taken on her first event without Prince Harry.The American visited Cheshire with The Queen earlier this month, appearing to be extremely close with the 92-year-old monarch.The pair even shared a joke as they took their seats for a childrens music medley performance.

title: uk weather forecast weekend latest temperatures isle of wight festival 2018
story: Temperatures were soaring as the 50th anniversary of the Isle of Wight music festival got underway.Brits will be able to bask in temperatures as hot as Spain with the mercury soaring to a sizzling 30C.The scorching heatwave will peak next Wednesday on what forecasters believe could be the hottest day of 2018.Average temperatures for this time of year usually hover around 21C in London, 18C in Manchester and 17C in Scotland.But from Saturday, forecasters expect widespread sunshine with temperatures rising 4C each day until the middle of next week.Martin Bowles from the Met Office said: Theres widespread sunshine for several days due.Over the weekend its going to stay sunny across the board almost everywhere.The temperature will be up a little bit each day.Saturday will see highs of 24C, and Sunday will enjoy highs of 25C in the South East and London, but temperatures will be well above average widely.He added: Monday 27C, Tuesday 28C, its quite likely, Id say more likely than not, that somewhere in the UK on Wednesday will get 30C, probably the South East of England.If Britain does hit 30C it will be as hot as Gibraltar and parts of southern Spain, such as Marbella, which are also forecast to be around 30C.Temperatures soared to a scorching 29.1C (84F) in St Jamess Park in London in April.The Meteogroup predicted Sunday and Monday would be dry and fine with a good deal of sunshine in most places, although the Shetland Islands would have the odd spot of drizzle.

title: army vet admits chewing off his mums head after cops find her decapitated remains in the back garden
story: Terrelle Johnson, 29, is said to have admitted killing mother Sherry after her decapitated body was found in their back garden in Stone County, Mississippi.Capt. Ray Boggs of the Stone County Sheriff’s Department recounted what was said at a preliminary hearing on Wednesday .According to the Sun Herald, he said: “(Johnson) told me that he beat her up real bad.“He said it got out of hand.”Using a butter knife, Johnson allegedly sliced his mother’s throat and then used his teeth and bare hands to remove her head, claimed Boggs.Johnson also claimed he choked her unconscious first during a fight over credit cards.When cops arrived at the Johnson home June 6 — to conduct a welfare check on Sherry at the request of her two brothers and sister, who hadn’t heard from the 51-year-old since June 3 — they found her mutilated body in the garden.Her head had been tossed over a fence.Johnson — an Army vet who was expelled by the Department of Veterans Affairs after a prior arrest — allegedly confessed to everything, though it’s unclear when his mother’s murder took place.A grand jury must now decide whether he should be formally charged.Johnson’s lawyer, Jim Davis, told reporters that he is currently weighing the possibility of an insanity defence.He said: “(Johnson) does have a substantial history and you all heard details of the case.“That’s not a normal homicide … (but) we’ve got to wait until we get the records and probably have him properly evaluated.“Then, we’ll kind of know where we’re headed.”

title: st pauls girls school hammersmith london austerity day baked potato lunch
story: St Pauls Girls School in Hammersmith, West London, was accused by a former pupil of showing utter contempt with the exercise that resulted in money going to local charities.The prestigious school, which counts Susanna Reid and Rachel Weisz as former pupils, usually serves the likes of seared cod, slow-cooked Moroccan lamb and duck leg confit, appeared to delete a post on Twitter about the austerity lunch.The post, which was screen-grabbed and shared, said: Today was the final Austerity Day of the year.Students and staff had baked potatoes, with beans and coleslaw, for lunch, with fruit for dessert.The money saved will be donated to the schools charities.The post included pictures of the food described, as well as an image of what appears to be the arm of a butler or waiter lifting a lid from a platter containing just three peas.Henna Shah, 24, a former bursary student at the school, said: I am incredibly grateful to have gone to a school that has given me opportunities someone like me would never have had otherwise.Yet I recognise that few people like me get the chance to have an education like this on a bursary scheme like I did.I am highlighting this now because this is not about pulling the ladder up behind me - I joined the Labour party and work in politics now precisely because everyone deserves the best quality education.It is upsetting to see that on a day that is meant to be about compassion, the way it was presented showed utter contempt.Austerity is not about eating jacket potatoes once a term, it is about not being able to afford anything else.A menu on the school website, for a week in May, gave a flavour of what is usually on offer for lunch at the school.Pupils tucked into delights such as Malaysian snapper Curry with okra and tomato, warm chicken and asparagus Caesar Salad, and plum and blackcurrant sponge.According to the schools website, the fee per term for the academic year 2017-2018 is £7,978, and for new entrants to the senior school (Year 12) the fee per term is £8,577.The school fee includes lunch, the website said.Susanna Reid - TV presenterA food section on the website says: Everyone knows teenage girls can be picky eaters, so we try to give them lots of choice.We regard the enjoyment of good and healthy food as a priority and lunch at St Pauls is a real highlight of the day.In a statement, the school said: For many years, along with many schools and places of worship in the country, St Pauls has arranged regular lunches when simple food is served and the money saved given to local charities.The aim is also to raise the awareness of our students to those less fortunate than themselves.We take our commitment to the wider community very seriously.The choice of the word austerity is to draw attention to the fact that others around them are facing significant economic difficulties.A Twitter account called @everydayhunger wrote: Can they really be unaware that for families living in poverty today, this austerity meal is completely out of reach?Maybe they should visit their local food bank to see what genuine poverty rations look like.Twitter user Georgia OBrien wrote: One of the countrys leading independent schools holding an Austerity Day where students eat what is basically amounts to a standard state school dinner.

title: prince andrew royal navy initiation pictures
story: The young officer was made to take part in a Crossing the Line ceremony to mark the first time he passed the equator as a seaman in 1982.The ritual involved a crew member of HMS Invincible dressing up as Neptune - the God of the Sea - to hold a court where novice sailors are put on trial for their sins.They then receive their punishment of being shaved with pink foam.In a nod to Prince Andrews Royal background, the photos show him sat down on makeshift throne with a cardboard crown placed on his head.Alarmingly, a seaman dressed as the barber is seen approaching the then second-in-line to the throne with a very large meat clever covered in imitation blood.The then 22-year-old Royal offers his neck towards the deadly instrument while the crew look in in amusement.Another snap shows the Duke of York roaring his head off in laughter during the ritual that took place while HMS Invincible sailed home from the Falklands War.The images make up a series of photos sent from the crew of the aircraft carrier to a brother and sister who wrote to them for autographs.The crew not only sent back a filled-in autograph book, with the Royal signing his name Andrew HRH, but also photographs of life on board including the initiation ceremony.They were sent by Lieutenant Commander Brian Prendergast.The images have now been put up for sale through Bosleys Auctioneers of Marlow, Bucks.Bernard Pass, of Bosleys, said: A couple of kids sent off this little autograph book to HMS Invincible for the crew to sign.But they didnt just get the book sent back they also got these photographs and a lovely covering letter from the commander of the aircraft carrier.They are all unpublished photographs taken by crew members rather than an official photographer.There are very amusing photos showing Prince Andrew’s ‘Crossing the Line’ ceremony.One snap that raises an eyebrow shows a man dressed as a barber holding an enormous meat clever and shaving brush but it looks like he is about to cut off the head of the then second-in-line to the throne.Other pictures in the gallery include Andrew in uniform being interviewed, shots of the deck of the ship and one of a Chinook helicopter lifting Sea Harrier jet.During the Falklands War, Prince Andrew risked his life by acting as a decoy to lure Argentine Exocet missiles away from HMS Invincible.He flew a Navy helicopter behind the aircraft carrier to make the missiles swerve towards the helicopter instead of the ship. He also flew on anti-submarine missions and search and rescue operations.The archive is tipped to sell for £200 at Bosleys on July 4.

title: england support at world cup lowest for 30 years supporters group says
story: It comes amid the strained ties between the UK and Russian governments following the poisoning of Russian ex-spy Sergei Skripal in Salisbury in March.MPs also raised concerns of a repeat of the violence seen in Marseille before and after England's match against Russia at Euro 2016.But the FSF such "dire warnings" had yet to become a reality."Over the years, regular travellers with England have had good reason to become sceptical about some of the dire warnings about the fate that could befall us at the next tournament," it said."If all we were told had been true, we would have been murdered in townships in South Africa, beaten up by racist hooligans in Ukraine or robbed at gunpoint in Brazilian favelas."It turns out that a little bit of common sense and preparation has generally been enough to keep us safe."The FSF added: "The big majority of Russian people have been immensely friendly, generous and welcoming."England fans above all should know from bitter experience the price that can be paid for judging everybody on the behaviour of a minority."As well as fears about violence, the supporters' group also cited the long distances, high costs and unlikely holiday feel to many host cities as factors stopping fans from travelling."The only sad thing about the whole experience is that the numbers of England fans who have been here to enjoy it have been so low," the FSF said."We reckon it's been probably the lowest number of England fans at a World Cup game for 30 years." The FSF added that Russia was not a "traditional" family holiday destination."We know there are a lot of other reasons why a lot of people have chosen to support the team from back home - there's the distances, the cost of travel, the inescapable fact that Russia isn't really a traditional family holiday destination."It's nonetheless a shame that some fans have been deterred from coming here because of disproportionate hype about the hooligan threat or political tensions," it continued.

title: final campaign push ahead of historic election in turkey
story: Polls suggest it is unlikely Mr Ince will win the presidency, but he could run close enough to force a second round on 8 July.Turkey faces a series of domestic and foreign problems: the Turkish lira has lost around a fifth of its value against the dollar in just a year, inflation has reached double digits, Turkish forces are engaged in action in Syria and Iraq, and there is an ongoing civil war with the Kurdish population in the south east of the country.In another challenge to President Erdogan, an unlikely coalition of opposition parties have teamed together to break the parliamentary majority enjoyed by his AKP party.The three parties, made up of secularists, nationalists and Islamists, make unlikely bedfellows, but have come together in an attempt to break Mr Erdogan's sixteen-year grip on power.If they do succeed in the parliamentary elections but Mr Erdogan is re-elected, Turkey could face months of political stalemate as each side tries to thwart the other. Turkey has lived under a state of emergency since an attempted coup in 2016."Erdogan became like a dictator in this country" an opposition activist told Sky."We have a lack of democracy, we have lack of justice, no education, nothing at all, so stealing is the big problem in this country."So even people supporting AKP - Mr Erdogan - are saying enough is enough. It's been sixteen years!"

title: glasgow school of art moves six inches after blaze that gutted building
story: She said: "Our building control officers are saying part of the building has moved quite significantly, about six inches."The elevation has shifted. There's a danger that part of the building may collapse."If that were to happen, it could happen with no warning."Therefore it's very, very important that no one enters the cordon - unless they are an accredited expert." It comes as police revealed they had received a report of a break-in at the nearby Campus on Sauchiehall Street around 3.20am on Thursday.The bar is inside the cordon, which was put up to seal off the area after the fire at the Mackintosh Building, and police are investigating.Glasgow City Council's head of building control Raymond Barlow said: "I fully understand people's desire to get back into their property and if we could safely do anything to facilitate that then we would."However surveys in recent days have shown us that the West and East elevations remain of significant concern."This means that there is a risk that parts of the building might fall into Scott Street or Dalhousie Street. This could happen without warning." More than 120 firefighters were involved in fighting the blaze.

title: dwp slammed asking writer help
story: NewsDWP slammed for asking writer to help 'empower' women into paid work... without paying herAmber Massie-Blomfield hit out at the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) in an open e-mail that she posted on Twitter&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter18:38, 22 JUN 2018NewsAmber Massie-Blomfield hit out at the Department for Work and Pensions (Image: Rosie Powell)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA writer has blasted the government for asking her to promote a campaign all about helping people into paid work... without actually paying her. Amber Massie-Blomfield hit out at the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) in an open e-mail that she posted on Twitter. She was asked to be part of the Her Way campaign, which aims to showcase routes into employment and empower women to craft their own future in work. The campaign declares: Women are often caught up in conflicting messages about their work: they ‘can’t’ do certain jobs or reach certain job levels, but at the same time are told to aspire to ‘have it all’. But when she asked to be paid for this task, she was told: Unfortunately, we can’t pay contributors - but would see it taking only a few hours of your time.   In a pithy email reply, Amber wrote: You will no doubt appreciate the irony of the DWP asking me to work with you as a contributor in this way without being paid. As an employee of the DWP, how would you advise I pay my mortgage, make my pension contribution, or indeed, feed myself, during the time I spend working, free-of-charge, on your campaign? Should I ask one of my other clients to subsidise DWP's campaign, or perhaps subsidise it myself, from the lavish income my life as a freelance arts professional affords?

title: pay rise armed forces demanded
story: NewsPay rise for armed forces demanded by Labour's defence chief as Theresa May attacked for starving them of cashShadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith is expected to back Trident to quell fears over Jeremy Corbyn’s commitment to the Armed Forces&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor22:04, 22 JUN 2018NewsNia Griffith will demand more money for troops (Image: Getty Images Europe)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour's defence chief will demand a pay rise for troops as she bids to exploit Tory divisions and quell fears over Jeremy Corbyn’s commitment to the Armed Forces. Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith is expected to back Trident, call for more money for the military and attack Theresa May for starving defence of cash when she addresses the Royal United Services Institute think tank on Monday. A source said: “In government the Tories have slashed defence spending, cut the size of the Army and are giving a raw deal to our servicemen and women. “Labour wants to see proper investment in defence and a decent pay rise for our men and women who have had to endure seven years of real terms pay cuts since 2010, despite rising rents in service accommodation and cuts to tax credits.”  The Prime Minister is under mounting pressure after she threw into doubt Britain’s status as a tier one military power. It is widely taken to mean a country which has a full spectrum of military capabilities, including nuclear weapons, special forces, a navy, army and air force capable of being deployed anywhere in the globe. She pointedly refuse to use the phrase when challenged this week, despite standing next to NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg in No 10. With the Army about 5,000 below its manpower target and repeated warnings about expensive equipment such as new stealth fighter jets and armoured vehicles widening the black hole in the defence budget, Labour believes the Tories are vulnerable over defence. This year’s Armed Forces Continuous Attitudes Survey, slipped out last month(MAY, revealed 35% of personnel are dissatisfied with Service life amid plunging morale.  Just 31% of troops are satisfied with their pay, a drop of 52% compared with when the Conservatives came to power in 2010. Ms Griffith’s speech to RUSI comes in the week of Armed Forces Day and ahead of next month’s(JULY) crunch NATO summit in Brussels where Donald Trump is expected to rap allies for failing to pump enough cash into their military. She was appointed to the tricky Shadow Defence Secretary post in October 2016 amid renewed scrutiny of Labour’s policies for the Armed Forces.

story: NewsPeople's Vote march on Brexit anniversary set to draw thousands of protesters - everything you need to knowTwo years to the day since the Brexit vote, pro-EU campaigners are taking to the streets in London&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter18:04, 22 JUN 2018NewsThousands of pro-EU protesters are expected to descend on central London (Image: AFP)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Tens of thousands of pro-EU protesters are expected to descend on central London on Saturday - two years to the day after Britain voted for Brexit . title: tory brexit playing russian roulette
story: NewsopinionThis Tory Brexit is playing Russian roulette with British jobsThe Airbus warning shows the Conservatives are putting tens of thousand of jobs at risk with their "dangerous" Brexit, writes Len McCluskey&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByLen McCluskey16:41, 22 JUN 2018NewsopinionAirbus has warned it could move out of the UK because of Brexit (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWell now we know what we always feared.  A Tory Brexit is dangerously bad for British jobs.       One of our foremost manufacturers, Airbus, has warned that without frictionless access to our European Union markets, it cannot see a future in the UK.       From the home of Concorde in Bristol, to Portsmouth and Newport, to Stevenage and Scotland, Airbus sustains 100,000 manufacturing and related jobs.      While the impact of any Airbus exit will fall heaviest on 6000 Broughton workers in North Wales, thousands more in the supply chain hang in the balance. There is not a part of the country that won’t suffer.         Yet the fate of these workers now lie in the hands of a squabbling Tory party.       It has been two years since the Brexit vote - but we are no further forward today in understanding where this government is taking us in March 2019 than we were in June 2016.       At this rate, hemmed in by the Tories’ destructive red lines, all the signs are that we will crash out without a deal.       So when the government breezily says that it is confident that it will get a deal that will meet the need of Airbus and manufacturers like them, who are they trying to kid?      People are not fools.  Yes, there was a vote to leave the EU – and that must be respected - but it was not a vote to lose our jobs.      The chill wind of a Tory Brexit is now blowing through our communities.

title: tory minister demands comedian ricky
story: NewsTory minister demands comedian Ricky Gervais apologises for branding ME sufferers 'lazy' in offensive jokeThe Office funnyman was accused of stigmatising the disease&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJohn SiddleNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent15:23, 22 JUN 2018Updated15:54, 22 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Government minister has demanded Ricky Gervais publicly apologise for a joke branding ME sufferers lazy. The Office funnyman was called out in a parliamentary debate and accused of stigmatising the disease. MP Steve Brine criticised Gervais for an old gag where he allegedly described ME as “the one where...‘I don’t feel like going to work today’. The Minister for Primary Care said: We recognise that people with ME have encountered significant stigma, in part due to the unfavourable media representations of the condition that not only go back to the 1980s but have continued in recent times Mr Brine used the the offensive joke as an example, telling MPs : I have to say that Ricky Gervais is a very talented comic but given that he’s quite active on Twitter, maybe he could just be asked to retract that and apologise to the ME community for that comment today on Twitter.”  The minister was speaking during a three-hour parliamentary debate on the lack of funding for medical research into ME. Politicians called for controversial psychotherapy and exercise therapies recommended by the NHS after a 'flawed' medical trial must stop because it is making patients worse.  They called for an end to stigma and myths surrounding ME. Westminster Hall was told how people with ME are more than six times likely to commit suicide. ME (myalgic encephalomyelitis) affects 250,000 people in the UK, with tens of thousands left bedbound, housebound and unable to work. Sufferers have had to face barbs of laziness and hysteria after the illness was dubbed ‘Yuppie Flu’ in the 1980s. Carol Monaghan (SNP, Glasgow North West) told the debate how ME costs the UK &pound3.3bn per year. She said: “Despite the number of people affected, and the devastating affect this disease has on suffers and indeed, their families, it is very much a hidden illness. “Characterised as ‘yuppie flu’, and misunderstood by doctors and politicians alike, it receives little funding, and treatment is often damaging.”

story: Advertorial11 best spots in the UK to watch an amazing sunset this summerThis week marks the summer solstice – and is also the official start of summer. Technically, this also means that the nights will start drawing in again now - so there's really no time like the present to get out and explore the great outdoors on some of the country’s most breathtaking bike rides. We've taken a look around the UK to find the best places to watch the sun setting.  1. title: abusive boyfriend made partner massage
story: NewsAbusive boyfriend made partner massage his hands after beating her because injuries ruined his workoutAuzair Hussain, 24, stopped his girlfriend from laughing, told her what she could eat, whipped her with a belt and prevented her from contacting friends and family&nbspShareByPhilip DeweyLucy Clarke-Billings17:11, 22 JUN 2018Updated17:15, 22 JUN 2018NewsHussain was convicted of coercive and controlling behaviour and assault occasioning ABH (Image: South Wales Police)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn abusive boyfriend made his partner massage his hands after he beat her because the pain affected his ability to bench press. Auzair Hussain reduced his girlfriend to a shadow of herself during a campaign to control her while they were both students at Cardiff politan University. From January to March last year, 24-year-old Hussain assaulted the French national on numerous occasions and whipped her with a belt and coat hanger. He controlled a number of aspects of his girlfriend’s life including the clothes and make-up she wore, what she ate, when she could shower, and who she was allowed to speak to while he also prevented her from speaking in her mother tongue and from contacting friends and family. He also hated her laughing and made her be quiet when she was in his presence.  A sentencing hearing at Newport Crown Court on Friday heard Hussain first attacked his victim after he saw her smoking a cigarette and she declined to hold his hand in public. It was at this stage he used the belt and hanger to whip his girlfriend, including her chest and private areas. On another occasion, after she looked at a LinkedIn account of a former boyfriend, Hussain threw her about, punched and kicked her, and strangled her before trashing her room. He told his terrified victim – who feared for her life and was so scared she wet herself – he would not hit her in the head because the head is for slapping. After another argument was started by the defendant, he punched and kicked his girlfriend and forced her to strip naked.  Straight after the assault Hussain went to the gym but complained his bench pressing had been affected by hand injuries sustained during the beating. She was later forced to massage his hands to soothe his injuries. Hussain, of Birmingham, was later convicted of coercive and controlling behaviour and assault occasioning ABH and he pleaded guilty to a count of assault occasioning ABH. In a statement read out to the court by prosecutor Sarah Waters, his victim said she felt destroyed as a person as a result of the relationship in which she felt trapped. She described the defendant as being extreme in everything he did and of pushing her beyond her boundaries. She said: I think it’s difficult for anyone who has not been in a controlling relationship to understand why I stayed with him but retrospectively I hate myself for being a coward and not running away. What should have been one of the best years of my life studying abroad turned into a nightmare.

title: dad who violently shook baby
story: NewsDad who violently shook baby son leaving him blind and brain damaged goes on run with new girlfriendKeith Ballard - who fled to Poland during his trial at Warwick Crown Court - has been sentenced to 18 years in prison for inflicting grievous bodily harm with intent on his young son Jake&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByPaul Beard17:38, 22 JUN 2018Updated17:48, 22 JUN 2018NewsBallard deliberately concealed that Jake had collapsed in his 111 NHS call (Image: Paul Beard / SWNS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dad who violently shook his newborn baby - causing catastrophic injuries which left him blind, deaf, quadriplegic and brain-damaged - has gone on the run. Keith Ballard, 31, fled to Poland with a new girlfriend during his trial at Warwick Crown Court. He was sentenced to 18 years in prison in his absence for inflicting grievous bodily harm with intent on his young son Jake, and cruelty by failing to get him emergency medical aid, Birmingham Live reports.  His then-partner, baby Jake’s mother Sharon Herbert was convicted of cruelty by neglecting him in a manner likely to cause unnecessary suffering by failing to get prompt treatment for him. When Ballard, of Coventry, failed to turn up, Judge Sally Hancox, issued a warrant for his arrest.  She was told a European arrest warrant would be applied for once he was convicted – but in fact, that application was not finalised until more than a week after the guilty verdicts. In the meantime, it emerged at Birmingham Crown Court, where Judge Hancox is now sitting, that the police had contacted Ballard’s new partner to tell her of the situation – and when she confronted him, he had got into his car and drove off. Concluding that there was no prospect that he will be found soon, Judge Hancox jailed him in his absence for 16 years for causing Jake’s injuries, with a consecutive two-year term for failing to get prompt medical attention. She ordered that when he is finally caught, he should be brought before her to be told of the sentence, and to be sentenced for absconding. Herbert, 33, of Coventry, was sentenced to two years in prison suspended for two years, with a 30-day rehabilitation activity.  Prosecutor Jonas Hankin QC said Jake, born in August 2015, was a normal healthy baby, with no sign of abnormality, after which routine screening showed him developing normally. He said: At midnight on the 9th of September, while at home in the sole care of his father Keith Ballard, Jake collapsed into a state of encephalopathy, damage to the brain affecting the function of the brain. Mr Ballard woke his partner Sharon Herbert, the child’s mother, who at the time was asleep in bed, and took Jake to her. She later said she knew immediately something was seriously wrong with Jake, whose condition she described as scary. There is consensus among medical experts that he would have been frighteningly unwell, and would have been frighteningly unwell at the point he sustained the injuries. Yet neither defendant called for an ambulance. Mr Hankin said after a delay of at least 10 minutes, Ballard called 111, the NHS non-emergency helpline, but even then he deliberately concealed the fact that Jake had collapsed. He merely described the 27-day-old baby as being a bit floppy when he got up to feed him – and Mr Hankin said Herbert had been a party to that misdescription.

title: former royal navy officer who
story: NewsFormer Royal Navy officer who groped junior crew member jailed for more than seven yearsCharles Howeson, 69, was convicted of 10 indecent assaults against eight young men in the 1980s and 1990s&nbspShareByClaire Hayhurst22:07, 22 JUN 2018Updated22:23, 22 JUN 2018NewsDisgraced former Royal Navy officer Charles Howeson was convicted of 10 indecent assaults against eight young men in the 1980s and 1990s (Image: Plymouth Herald / SWNS)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA former commander in the Royal Navy and former senior member of staff at Coutts has been jailed for seven years and six months for indecently assaulting eight young men. Charles Howeson, 68, used his qualities, advantages and power to act as a sexual predator towards young men while in three separate roles between 1985 and 1994. He was convicted of 10 indecent assaults against eight young men during that period, following a trial at Bristol Crown Court last year. The court heard he was the effective captain of HMS Cleopatra in 1985 and groped a junior member of crew on an unlit deck. A Royal Navy inquiry was launched after the victim, and a second man who reported Howeson for touching his stomach and tugging at his shirt, complained. Judge Mark Horton said senior officers associated with Howeson effectively closed ranks and put his interests, and the reputation of the Navy, above those whom it should have been protecting. Howeson was given a formal warning by the Royal Navy and never commanded a ship of the fleet again - though was promoted - and retired in 1990.  He then worked as a chief executive at a charity in Plymouth, where he indecently assaulted six volunteers in dark tunnels on Drake's Island and dark rooms. Complaints were made but the allegations were not reported to police to save the reputation of the trust, the judge said, and Howeson was allowed to resign. Following his resignation, Howeson saw a further opportunity to manipulate and assault another young man. The judge ordered Howeson, of Craigie Drive, Plymouth, to pay prosecution costs of &pound50,000 and sign the sex offenders register indefinitely. This case has revealed that to the outside world you displayed the finest qualities of diplomacy, charisma, endeavour, organisation and charm which you demonstrated during your period in the Navy and in your extensive and successful career and involvement at the very highest level with public bodies, authorities, businesses including a bank but also in your public and charitable works mainly associated with the community of Plymouth, the judge told Howeson. The hidden and dark truth is these same qualities were the very qualities which enabled you to mask and conceal a dark secret only revealed for the world to see some 30 years later in this trial. That secret was your uncontrolled and predatory sexual behaviour particularly towards young or at least vulnerable men under your control. Between 1985 and 1994, in three separate roles in your professional life, you used all of your qualities, advantages and power to use and abuse your position to enable you to act as a sexual predator. In most cases you effectively trapped them like prey in order to abuse them.

title: how last victoria cross holder
story: NewsHow last Victoria Cross holder 'Big Bill' hurled rocks and beer cans to keep the North Korean army at bayBill Speakman died aged 90, 66 years after he fought off a sustained attack from 6,000 solders for more than four hours with a shrapnel wound in his leg&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByLaura Connor21:08, 22 JUN 2018Updated21:10, 22 JUN 2018NewsVictoria Cross holder Bill Speakman with his medals (Image: REX/Shutterstock)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe only living Victoria Cross holder from the Korean War has died at the age of 90. War hero Bill Speakman was just 24 when he fought off a sustained attack from 6,000 Chinese and North Korean solders for more than four hours in 1951, despite receiving a shrapnel wound in his leg. The 6ft 6in soldier, known as ‘Big Bill’, pelted enemy soldiers with grenades until they ran out. He then hurled rocks, tins and even empty beer bottles at them. He was given a hero’s welcome by thousands of people on the streets of his hometown of Altrincham, Greater Manchester, when he returned a year later. Speakman became the first man to receive a Victoria Cross from Queen Elizabeth II for outstanding bravery, and was one of only a handful of living holders of the award.  Despite his great height and courage, he was known as a modest and quiet man who struggled to adjust to civilian life and the celebrity which followed his great investiture. Born on September 21, 1927, Bill was raised by a single mum and started his military career when he was 17, serving in Germany, Italy and Hong Kong with the Black Watch, 3rd Battalion, Royal Regiment of Scotland. He transferred to the King’s Own Scottish Borderers (KOSB) as a private when British troops mobilised for Korean service in 1950.  His regiment was bombarded with shell and mortar fire in the early hours of November 4, 1951 as they defended a position on Maryang San in Korea, but Speakman fought back with grenades and beer bottles sent to the line for consumption by the platoon, breaking up several enemy attacks. His charge against the enemy allowed his overrun troops enough time to evacuate their wounded. Talking of the life-or-death seige, he said: “It was hand-to-hand. There was no time to pull back the bolt of the rifle. “It was November, the ground was hard, so grenades bounced and did damage.”  Recalling the moment he was handed the award, he said: “When I got it The King [George VI] was alive but he was very ill. “He awarded me the VC and then he died. So The Queen – I was her first VC. It was a wonderful moment. I think she was nervous and I was very nervous.” The announcement of the Victoria Cross award said: “Private Speakman’s heroism under intense fire throughout the operation and when painfully wounded was beyond praise and is deserving of supreme recognition.”

title: plus size model fuelling obesity
story: NewsPlus-size model are fuelling obesity crisis by “normalising” being overweight says expertsExperts found the number of people underestimating their size has grown alongside the body-positivity movement&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science Correspondent19:47, 22 JUN 2018NewsA plus-sized model appears on the runway (Image: Getty Images North America)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe rise in plus-size fashion ranges and models is fuelling the obesity crisis by “normalising” being overweight, experts suggest. They found the number of people underestimating their size has grown alongside the body-positivity movement. Analysis showed 58% of overweight men thought in 2015 they were slimmer than they really were, up from 48% in 1997. The same applied to 31% of women, compared with 25% in 2015.  People underestimating their size were 85% less likely to try to slim down. Prof Dr Raya Muttarak, University of East Anglia, said: “Seeing the potential of the fuller-sized market, retailers may have contributed to normalisation of being overweight and obese. “While [the] body-positive movement helps reduce stigmatisation, it can potentially undermine the recognition of being overweight and its health consequences.

title: posh 8000 term school slammed
story: NewsPosh £8,000-a-term school slammed for its 'austerity day' lunch of baked potatoes with beans and coleslawSt Paul's Girls' School in Hammersmith, west London, was accused of showing 'utter contempt' with the exercise&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByBradley Jolly22:11, 22 JUN 2018NewsSt Paul's Girls' School in Hammersmith, west London, charges £8,000 every term (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A top private school which charges &pound8,000 each term has been slammed for serving baked potatoes for its  austerity day lunch.  Former pupils of St Paul's Girls' School in Hammersmith, west London, said it showed utter contempt for describing jacket potatoes with beans and coleslaw as an austerity meal today. The exercise, which saw money go to charities, has also led to widespread criticism on social media. The prestigious school usually serves its 700 students the likes of seared cod, slow-cooked Moroccan lamb and duck leg confit for lunch. But it altered its lavish menu for the day and donated the money saved to charity.  In a tweet which appears to have been deleted, the school said: Today was the final Austerity Day of the year. Students and staff had baked potatoes, with beans and coleslaw, for lunch, with fruit for dessert. The money saved will be donated to the school's charities.   But Henna Shah, 24, a former St Paul's student, said: I am incredibly grateful to have gone to a school that has given me opportunities someone like me would never have had otherwise. Yet I recognise that few people like me get the chance to have an education like this on a bursary scheme like I did. I am highlighting this now because this is not about pulling the ladder up behind me — I joined the Labour party and work in politics now precisely because everyone deserves the best quality education.         Henna, of Hounslow, west London, added: It is upsetting to see that on a day that is meant to be about compassion, the way it was presented showed utter contempt. Austerity is not about eating jacket potatoes once a term, it is about not being able to afford anything else. And a Twitter account called @everydayhunger wrote: Can they really be unaware that for families living in poverty today, this 'austerity' meal is completely out of reach? Maybe they should visit their local food bank to see what genuine poverty rations look like. Twitter user Georgia O'Brien wrote: One of the country's leading independent schools holding an 'Austerity Day' where students eat what is basically amounts to a standard state school dinner. Pupils at the school usually tuck into delights such as Malaysian snapper Curry with okra and tomato and warm chicken and asparagus Caesar Salad.  According to the school's website, the fee per term for the academic year 2017-2018 is &pound7,978, and for new entrants to the senior school (Year 12) the fee per term is &pound8,577. The school fee includes lunch, the website said. A food section on the website says: Everyone knows teenage girls can be picky eaters, so we try to give them lots of choice. We regard the enjoyment of good and healthy food as a priority and lunch at St Paul's is a real highlight of the day.

title: sas who dares wins star
story: NewsSAS: Who Dares Wins star who heard his wife being stabbed to death is engaged to woman who helped rebuild his lifeDad of two, Dan Cross, whose wife, Nicola, was attacked by a schizophrenic home intruder, will wed mental health clinician Alex Wells next year&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByLiz Dunphy10:17, 22 JUN 2018Updated14:02, 22 JUN 2018News&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSAS: Who Dares Wins star Dan Cross who heard his wife being stabbed to death over the phone is engaged to the remarkable woman who has helped rebuild his life. The dad of two, who listened helplessly as wife Nicola was attacked by a schizophrenic home intruder, will wed mental health clinician Alex Wells next year after dating for 15 months.  He said: I'm engaged to Alex. She's a remarkable woman. We're moving forward and hopefully going to get married next year. The children are really happy, he told BBC Three Counties Radio .  Nikki, 37, was brutally killed in September 2015 as she tried to protect her two children Stanley, six, and Isabella, three, from 25-year-old Marcin Porczynski who had broken into their home in Hemel Hempstead, Hertfordshire.  Dan, 40, was at work 200 miles away in Hull when he heard Nicola's screams down the phone as she pleaded for her life before she was stabbed 10 times. Porczynski later pleaded guilty at St Albans Crown Court to Nikki's manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility and was ordered to be detained in a secure psychiatric unit for an indefinite period.   You can listen to Dan's full interview on BBC Three Counties Radio here.    Speaking about finding love with Alex, 27, while dealing with the heartache of losing Nicola, Dan revealed that he has his late wife's blessing explaining: We had that chat. We had discussed what would happen if one of us died young. Nikki said 'I want you to be happy. I want you to find someone else, someone that can look after the kids'. I was the clown and would say 'If I die young, I want you to wear black for the rest of your life and never meet anyone else'. We had the conversation so every day from the day Nikki died decision making was always based around what would Nikki do, what would Nikki want and we still do that today.  Nikki wanted me to be happy. She wanted the children to be happy. She was that type of person and that gives me confidence knowing I'm doing the right thing. I honestly believed for a long time that I would never meet anybody else and then gradually things changed and I began to realise that I didn't want to be on my own for the rest of my life and I knew what Nikki wanted for me. I was worried when I initially thought I was ready to start dating again,'Who would want to now?'   London Marathon cheat who crossed finish line with another runner's number to see a dream come true jailed  This is a guy who is seriously damaged goods, he's got a lot of baggage with him and Alex just takes it all in her stride. She's great with the kids. She's a mental health clinician and knows exactly how to deal with them. They love her to bits. Brave Dan, who following Nicola's death set up the charity Nikki's Wishes to help children who have suffered from bereavement in his late wife's memory, says they will never forget her. Dan added: There will always be that sadness that Nikki is not around. We'll always miss her. We'll always love her. We'll always remember her. We have to keep moving forward as well as holding onto that nice bit of the past. We do, obviously, have our daily issues that we need to address around the event of what happened to Nikki and that will continue, but in general we are a positive family and we'll keep being so.     Dan first revealed he had found love again back in January when he appeared on This Morning. He said: A year ago this weekend I met Alex, she's fitted beautifully into our lives. It's a brave decision to get involved with a family like this, she's a mental health clinician and she can do things with the kids. She does memory boxes where you use your hands and other techniques to bring back memories. It's been amazing, quite freaky really to have someone come in who's so perfect.      Speaking to Holly Willoughby and Phillip Schofield, Dan explained how counselling has helped him and his children to deal with the trauma.  He said: Stanley was six and Isabella was three at the time, I was telling her to leave and go to my mum and dad's but before she could leave he broke through the back doors and killed her. I didn't know what happened to the children until I heard them crying on the phone, and knew they were okay. Dan and his children moved in with his parents after the horrific night, but he returns to his former home sometimes so he can let out his emotions in private and feel closer to Nikki.  Dan underwent trauma counselling afterwards and said he experienced flashbacks within the first month after Nicola died. I felt like I couldn't breathe, I was back in that moment and then I realised if I'm going to be a good dad to the kids and make sure they're confident, happy adults then I need to get help, he said. Viewers of the Channel 4 show SAS: Who Dares Wins were reduced to tears when Dan spoke about how his children motivated him to survive their family tragedy.

title: shipwreck looters who plundered historical
story: NewsShipwreck looters who plundered historical artefacts from Royal Navy warship at bottom of the sea jailedAmong at least 100 items Nigel Ingram, 57, and John Blight, 58, failed to disclose were a torpedo hatch, launch panels and chinaware&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJoe MiddletonCharlotte Neal21:53, 22 JUN 2018NewsThe pair failed to declare more than 100 items (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShipwreck divers who plundered historical artefacts from the wreck of a Royal Navy warship have been jailed. Nigel Ingram, 57, and John Blight, 58, were found guilty of failing to disclose more than 100 items of unreported wreck from the HMS Hermes in the English Channel - including a torpedo hatch, launch panels and chinaware. The two men were found at the location of the HMS Hermes by French maritime officers on Tuesday September 30 2014. Ingram was still in the water at the time, having dived from Blight’s boat called De Bounty. Although no offences were identified at the time officers were suspicious of the lifting equipment on the boat, resulting in an underwater exploration of the Hermes three days later.  HMS Hermes was a protected cruiser built in the late 19th century and converted into an aircraft ferry and depot ship ready for the start of the First World War. It was sunk by a German submarine in the Dover Strait in October 1914, causing the loss of 44 British lives. After the exploration a criminal investigation was launched by the French authorities and later referred to Kent Police, resulting in the arrests of Ingram and Blight on Monday October 19, 2015. More than 100 items of unreported wreck were recovered at Ingram’s home along with approximately &pound16,000 cash.  A number of photographs were also located on his computer, one of which showed the condenser of the Hermes on the back of De Bounty approximately four hours after it had been boarded by the French surveillance officers. Police established through subsequent enquiries that Ingram had cashed a cheque from a scrap merchant for &pound5,029 the day after, on Wednesday, October 1 2014. Also seized from Ingram’s home was a notebook entitled ‘De Bounty, Diver Recovery’ that contained details of what dives were undertaken and the items recovered, including the condenser. The total value of the wreck collected was estimated at being more than &pound150,000.  None of the items listed were reported to the Receiver of Wreck as they should have been. Ian Hope, prosecuting, said the pair hauled huge pieces of wrecks from the seabed using winching equipment on Mr Blight's boat. They deliberately and dishonestly failed to declare them to the authorities, as they were legally obligated to do, On Friday June 22 2018 both men were found guilty of fraud relating to their failure to disclose recovered items in order to make a financial gain, following a two-week trial at Canterbury Crown Court. Ingram, from Teynham, Kent was subsequently jailed for four years and Blight from Winchelsea, East Sussex for three-and-a-half years. Investigating officer PC Anne Aylett, of Kent Police, said: The HMS Hermes and other shipwrecks of its kind are legally protected for a reason, and that is because they form an important part of the history of this country.  Nigel Ingram and John Blight have demonstrated a complete disregard for the law by helping themselves to artefacts that should have remained beneath the sea instead of being brought to the surface and sold for scrap metal. We are proud of our close working relationship with our partner agencies, which in this case included the Maritime and Coastguard Agency, the Marine Management Organisation, the Receiver of Wreck, Sussex Police, Historic England, Crown Prosecution Service and the French authorities, and take a robust approach to ensuring important historical items do not end up in the hands of people who are not entitled to them. We will continue to investigate anyone suspected of stealing items from sunken wrecks and seek to prosecute them when appropriate. Mark Harrison, head of heritage crime and policing advice for Historic England, said: All archaeological sites underwater comprise a finite, irreplaceable and fragile resource, vulnerable to damage and destruction through human activity.

story: NewsUber driver 'armed with samurai sword and who attacked police outside Buckingham Palace didn't intend to harm innocent people'Mohiussunnath Chowdhury, 27, drove his blue Toyota Prius at a marked police van in Westminster in August last year&nbspShareByBecca Speare-ColeBradley Jolly21:20, 22 JUN 2018NewsMohiussunnath Chowdhury denies the terror charge (Image: Julia Quenzler / SWNS)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn Uber driver who was allegedly armed with a samurai sword and attacked police officers outside Buckingham Palace claimed he was just trying to get himself killed by cops. Mohiussunnath Chowdhury, 27, travelled more than 35 miles to ram his blue Toyota Prius at a marked police van on August 25, 2017. A court heard today he was sprayed with CS gas and arrested after he reached for the blade and scuffled with two officers. The two officers had to be rushed to hospital.  Counter-terrorist police recovered evidence of extremist internet searches and WhatsApp messages saying he supported Isis from his handset. The taxi driver told the Old Bailey: I felt lonely and depressed. I told my sister I didn't want to live anymore. My intention was only to show the sword to a soldier or the police and so get them to shoot me. If I was going to do any acts of terrorism, I could have got out the car with my sword when Mr Gavin was approaching. I had so many chances. I reject the allegations of terrorism.  Chowdhury, from Luton, Beds., said he had felt guilty being a citizen of the United Kingdom while Muslims in Yemen were being killed by weapons that the government sold to Saudi Arabia. He continued: I came across articles criticising the UK government for selling weapons to Saudi Arabia who were killing these people. Since I realised we were giving aid to them and at the same time providing the weapons for them to be killed, I thought this was a massive contradiction. I felt depressed and guilty. I felt I was also responsible for the decisions taken by my government while my family were dying.  I had to shun these people, and show my disapproval. At the time I did not know not to do it. There was nothing I could do. I just wanted to disassociate myself from my governments decision. But Timothy Cray, prosecuting, claimed Chowdhury had always intended to scare people in Westminster, less than six months after a horrific terrorist attack there killed five innocent citizens . Mr Cray said: Your intention at the very least was to make sure you would do as much as you could possibly do to get lethal force with the firing of a weapon in a public place, right in the centre of London. Think about it now, there were people there. Anybody seeing the discharging of lethal force on the street would be scared.

title: woman spends seven years hunting
story: NewsWoman spends seven years hunting for long-lost sister - only to discover she's moved in next doorHillary Harris, 31, was stunned to discover the person sharing her driveway was the sibling she'd never met, and the pair hit it off immediately.&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByPatricia Murphy15:31, 22 JUN 2018NewsHillary (right) is pictured with her sister Dawn (Image: SWNS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A woman who spent seven years hunting for her long-lost sister discovered she was living next door - after spotting her name on a delivery.  Hillary Harris, 31, was stunned to find the person sharing her driveway was the sibling she'd never met, and the pair hit it off immediately. Describing how she felt when she realised, she said: “I began to shake. It was such an intense moment. Hillary knew her sibling was called Dawn Johnson and noticed that name on an item of post in her building. Stunned, she plucked up courage to speak to Dawn, 50, and they discovered that they had the same father, Wayne Clouse. Hillary and her biological brother Tyler Hardy, 33, were adopted in 1987 by Lee Hardy, 65, and his late wife Rochelle.  The childcare worker began the search for her biological family when she became pregnant with her daughter Stella, now seven, in 2011. Her adoption agency revealed the names of her birth parents but she was heartbroken to discover her father Wayne Clouse had died in 2002. When going through her file, Hillary discovered her late father’s obituary which mentioned his daughters Dawn Johnson and Renee Diericks, 49,  Hillary, of Eau Claire, Wisconsin, had searched for Wayne's daughters on Facebook but had been unsuccessful in tracking them down.  Then in June 2017, a woman named Dawn and her partner Kurt Casperson, 53, moved in next door. Hillary thought nothing of it at first, but in August she saw Dawn’s last name on a package being delivered.  She struck up the courage to ask her new neighbor who her father was via text and Dawn, a lab processor, confirmed her suspicions. Stunned Hillary said: “For me this is 100 per cent fate. I was so sad when I discovered my biological father had passed away. But by meeting Dawn I feel like I have all the answers I will ever need. She’s the missing puzzle piece I have been looking for for so many years. “For me something first clicked in June when I found out her name was Dawn and she was from Greenwood. My husband and I joked for a few weeks that she was my sister but we didn’t know her last name. “One day she got a delivery of shingles for her roof and it was addressed to Dawn Johnson, the same name in Wayne’s obituary. “I began to shake. It was such an intense moment.  “It was late at night, but I finally got the courage to text her and ask her who her dad was. She confirmed it was Wayne. I told her we had a lot to talk about and she said, 'We have the same dad don’t we?' Hillary said that since then they have grown very close. She said when she met her birth mum she thought she would have an immediate bond but she didn't. Yet with Dawn, there was a connection straight away. Dawn, who did not grow up with her father but formed a relationship with him later in life, added: “It’s such a weird coincidence. “Of all the hundreds of thousands of homes we bought a house that shares a driveway with my sister. “I was ecstatic and so was my sister Renee. She couldn’t believe it.”

story: NewsGirl, six, is raped, murdered and mutilated by stranger who 'lured her from wedding with promise of ice cream'WARNING: DISTRESSING AND GRAPHIC CONTENT Chilling CCTV footage has been released showing the small child following a man into the street in India&nbspShareByKelly-Ann Mills11:39, 22 JUN 2018Updated17:29, 22 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA six-year-old girl was raped, murdered and mutilated after being lured away from a family wedding with the promise of ice cream Haunting CCTV shows the small child, in a floor-length white dress, following a man into the street in Gwalior, Madhya Pradesh, in India, on Wednesday evening. She was last seen holding the man's hand disappearing into darkness at around 11.30pm. The man is later seen returning alone three hours later at around 2.30am. Police began a desperate hunt for the little girl after her parents realised she was missing and her body was found on a hillock 500 metre from the venue in the early hours of Thursday morning.  She had been raped then strangled. Police said a stone had been used to disfigure her face 'beyond recognition'. A man, believed to be a member of the wedding catering team, has been arrested on suspicion of murder. Dharmraj Meena, the Senior Superintendent of Police of Gwalior, said: “Our team reached the spot along with the forensic experts, after seeing the crime scene it is quite clear that the child had undergone a brutal sexual assault. The criminal had used a big stone to smash her face and kill her.  We have started an investigation and the culprit will be nabbed soon, right now we have zeroed in on one person who is a part of the catering team, we are questioning him for further leads.”  The victim had been sleeping with her family at the wedding venue and had got up to get water when she vanished, according to The Free Press Journal. She went to a water point there to quench her thirst. When she did not return, her family launched a search, but failed to find her,'an official said. Police said she had been lured away with the promise of ice cream. A post mortem confirmed that she had been sexually assaulted. The case is the latest in a string of horrific rapes and murders which have rocked India over the last few years. In 2012, Jyoti Singh, a young woman who dreamed of being a physiotherapist, was assaulted on a bus.  Her injuries were so severe she later died, sparking mass protests, outrage and a call for change in a society where women face huge discrimination and live in fear of sexual assault. Despite the outcry, there has been little change since Jyoti's death at the age of 23.

story: NewsMeet the 'throuple' of polyamorous lovers who have regular threesomes, plan to marry and want children togetherNatalie Fink, 22, is in a relationship with both Yannick Gwarys and Michael Flamm — but they claim they never get jealous&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAlex Shipman18:51, 22 JUN 2018Updated19:10, 22 JUN 2018NewsMichael Flamm (left), Yannick Gwarys (middle) and Natalie Fink (right) have regular threesomes (Image: Natalie Fink / SWNS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A trio of polyamorous lovers has regular threesomes and plan to marry and have children together.
